> [!quote] [[Maclane - Categories for the Working Mathematician.pdf#page=66\|Saunders Mac Lane]]
> The notion of Kan extensions subsumes all the other fundamental concepts in category theory.

## Motivation
---

Suppose $T:M\to A$ and $K:M\to C$ are two functors from a common domain, suggestively diagrammed below^[Here I'm using the exact notation Mac Lane uses in *Categories for the Working Mathematician*, in case you want to reference his exposition.]:

We are interested in functors $S:C\to A$ that "extend" the functor $T:M\to A$ "along" the functor $K:M\to C$.

For example, if the functor $K:M\to C$ is fully faithful (i.e., is the categorical version of an inclusion), then for any functor $S:C\to A$ we can view the composition $S\circ K:M\to A$ as the "restriction" of $S$ to $M$. In this case, we might hope for the existence of a functor $S:C\to A$ that literally extends the functor $T$, in the sense that $T = S\circ K$.

In general, the best we can do is the following: for each functor $S:C\to A$, we can "compare" the composition $S\circ K$ with the functor $T$ by looking at the set of natural transformations between the two. More specifically, we consider either the set of natural transformations $\operatorname{Hom}_{A^M}(S\circ K, T)$, or dually the set of natural transformations $\operatorname{Hom}_{A^M}(T, S\circ K)$. For now, let's focus on the latter.

Our first claim is that the map $S\mapsto \operatorname{Hom}_{A^M}(T, S\circ K)$ is the object function of a functor $F:A^C\to {\bf Set}$. What is the arrow function? Suppose $\alpha:S_1\Rightarrow S_2$ is an arrow in $A^C$, i.e., a natural transformation between functors $S_1, S_2: C\to A$. Let $I_K:K\Rightarrow K$ be the identity natural transformation on the functor $K:M\to C$. "Horizontal" composition of the natural transformations $I_K$ and $\alpha$ then gives a natural transformation $\alpha\circ I_K:(S_1\circ K)\Rightarrow (S_2\circ K)$. We can visualize this horizontal composition as so:

rotate(0 10.29909843488393 4.005204946899312)"><use href="#image-2d115ac95142aeef1b6caf6c04097f03a702fcaf" width="21" height="8" opacity="1"/></g></svg>

More concretely, the components of this natural transformation are given by $(\alpha\circ I_K)_m = \alpha_{K(m)}.$ In other words, they are simply the components of the natural transformation $\alpha$ "restricted" to the objects in the image of $K$.

We can now use "vertical" composition with the natural transformation $\alpha\circ I_K$ to define a set map

$$F(\alpha):\operatorname{Hom}_{A^M}(T, S_1\circ K)\to \operatorname{Hom}_{A^M}(T, S_2\circ K),$$

namely by mapping each natural transformation $\beta:T\Rightarrow (S_1\circ K)$ to the (vertical) composition $(\alpha\circ I_K)\circ \beta:T\Rightarrow (S_2\circ K)$.

rotate(89.62384644305958 13.98514133029514 7.866641998291016)"><use href="#image-a37d34359086408a22b3fe0a91a61ed3b0e672e7" width="28" height="16" opacity="1"/></g><g transform="translate(116.65094043300819 39.96362941438349) rotate(0 6.9650404085117845 6.529725382979791)"><use href="#image-3d387f3e639dee0e7eac7ccdf08582ec5c2d8801" width="14" height="13" opacity="1"/></g><g transform="translate(120.40933834955683 81.95010972782728) rotate(0 19.431280037035275 5.741060010942235)"><use href="#image-d3bf8865520264b7d65f74b88b956162476b8cb8" width="39" height="11" opacity="1"/></g></svg>

In other words,

$$F(\alpha)=(\alpha\circ I_K)\circ -$$

You can now verify that we have indeed defined a functor $F:A^C\to {\bf Set}$. We can interpret this functor as an exhaustive analysis of every possible functor $S:C\to A$ as a candidate for "extending" the original functor $T:M\to A$ "along" the functor $K:M\to C$.

## Definition of Kan extension
---

> [!note] Definition of left Kan extension
> Suppose the functor $F:A^C\to {\bf Set}$ described above is representable, i.e., there exists an object $L\in A^C$ together with a natural isomorphism $\tau:\operatorname{Hom}_{A^C}(L,-)\overset{\sim}\Rightarrow F$.
> 
> By Yoneda's Lemma, the object $L$ is then unique up to unique isomorphism. It is called the **left Kan extension of $T$ along $K$**, and is denoted $\operatorname{Lan}_K(T)$ (or sometimes simply ${}_KT$).


Let's unpack this definition a bit. In view of the definition of the functor $F:A^C\to {\bf Set}$, the defining property of the functor $\operatorname{L}_K(T):C\to A$ is that we have natural bijections

$$\tau_S:\operatorname{Hom}_{A^C}(\operatorname{Lan}_K(T),S)\xrightarrow{\sim}\operatorname{Hom}_{A^M}(T, S\circ K).$$

The reason the functor $\operatorname{Lan}_K(T)$ is called the *left* Kan extension is because it occurs on the left-hand side of its hom-set in the above bijection. As you might expect, the *right* Kan extension (when it exists) is a functor $\operatorname{Ran}_K(T):C\to A$ such that there are natural bijections

$$\eta_S:\operatorname{Hom}_{A^C}(S,\operatorname{Ran}_K(T))\xrightarrow{\sim}\operatorname{Hom}_{A^M}(S\circ K, T).$$

In both cases, the above bijections should look very similar to adjoint relationships, and indeed we'll see that: 1) adjoints are a special case of Kan extensions; and 2) if the left Kan extension along $K$ of every functor $T$ exists, then we do indeed have a functor $\operatorname{Lan}_K(-):A^M\to A^C$ that is left adjoint to the "restriction" functor $-\circ K:A^C\to A^M$ (and similarly for the right Kan extension).

> [!info] Local versus Global
> The definition given above is sometimes called a **local** Kan extension, while the functor $\operatorname{Lan}_K:A^C\to A^M$ that is left adjoint to the restriction functor $-\circ K:A^C\to A^M$ is called the **global** Kan extension.

## Examples of Kan extensions
---

### Starting with a category $C$ and nothing else

Suppose $C$ is any category. In general, there are only three functors to/from $C$ that are guaranteed to exist:
- The unique (empty) functor $i_C:{\bf 0}\to C$ from the initial (empty) category. (We've denoted this functor $i_C$ as shorthand for the "initial functor to $C$.)
- The identity functor $I_C:C\to C$
- The unique functor $t_C:C\to {\bf 1}$ to the terminal (one-object) category. (We've denoted this functor $t_C$ as shorthand for the "terminal functor to $C$.)

We can now consider every possible Kan extension that involves one (or more) of these three functors. Many choices lead to "trivial" extensions, but some lead to interesting conclusions. For example, consider the situation below:

transform="translate(64.40205708842484 118.88058400617223) rotate(0 8.019207710721332 6.515606264961065)"><use href="#image-12682fcca83c8bf1e46c194ecb11764ef4686bb8" width="16" height="13" opacity="1"/></g><g transform="translate(10 69.62802455874368) rotate(0 9.082951062292466 4.238710495736484)"><use href="#image-947eb6cbe021218016aa513e666a76754d16ae9d" width="18" height="8" opacity="1"/></g></svg>

Let's first suppose the left Kan extension of the initial functor $i_C:{\bf 0}\to C$ along the (unique, emtpy) functor $z:{\bf 0}\to {\bf 1}$ exists, and denote it $L:{\bf 1}\to C$. Recall that we have an equivalence $C^{\bf 1}\simeq C$, where each functor ${\bf 1}\to C$ corresponds to an object $c\in C$ (namely, the image of the unique object $\bullet \in {\bf 1}$). So, given any functor $S:{\bf 1}\to C$ we can let $s\in C$ denote the corresponding object. The left Kan extension $L:{\bf 1}\to C$ then corresponds to an object $l\in C$, characterized by existence of natural bijections

$$\tau_S: \operatorname{Hom}_{C^{\bf 1}}(L,S)\xrightarrow{\sim} \operatorname{Hom}_{C^{\bf 0}}(t_C,S\circ K).$$

The set on the left is (bijective to) the set $\operatorname{Hom}_C(l,s)$ under the equivalence $C^{\bf 1}\simeq C$. Similarly, under the equivalence $C^{\bf 0}\simeq {\bf 1}$, the set on the right is simply the singleton set $\{\bullet\}$. (The composition $S\circ K:{\bf 0}\to C$ must always equal the unique functor $t_ C$, and the only natural transformation from the functor $t_C$ to itself is the identity (empty) natural transformation.)

So, for every object $s\in C$ the set $\operatorname{Hom}_C(l,s)$ is a singleton set. In other words, for every object $s\in C$ there is a unique arrow $l\to c$. This exactly says that $l$ is an initial object in $C$.

One can fairly easily show that the converse is true, namely that if $C$ has an initial object then the left Kan extension of $i_C:{\bf 0}\to C$ along $z:{\bf 0}\to {\bf 1}$ exists (and is the functor $L:{\bf 1}\to C$ corresponding to that initial object). Thus, we have the following:

> [!summary] Initial objects as left Kan extensions
> A category $C$ has an initial object if and only if the left Kan extension of $i_C:{\bf 0}\to C$ along $z:{\bf 0}\to {\bf 1}$ exists.

Dually, a similar argument proves:

> [!summary] Terminal objects as right Kan extensions
> A category $C$ has a terminal object if and only if the right Kan extension of $i_C:{\bf 0}\to C$ along $z:{\bf 0}\to {\bf 1}$ exists.

---

Somewhat curiously, we can also realize initial objects as *right* Kan extensions. In this case, we begin from the diagram

opacity="1"/></g><g transform="translate(10 68.2737707241809) rotate(0 6.883648406522184 5.5929643302992815)"><use href="#image-947eb6cbe021218016aa513e666a76754d16ae9d" width="14" height="11" opacity="1"/></g></svg>

One can then show the following:

> [!summary] Initial objects as right Kan extensions
> A category $C$ has an initial object if and only if the right Kan extension of the identity functor $I_C:C\to C$ along the terminal functor $t_C:C\to {\bf 1}$ exists.

The proof of the above statement is slightly less straightforward than the previous argument, but is not terribly difficult (and follows immediately as a special case of the next type of example). And analogously, we have the dual result:

> [!summary] Terminal objects as left Kan extensions
> A category $C$ has a terminal object if and only if the left Kan extension of the identity functor $I_C:C\to C$ along the terminal functor $t_C:C\to {\bf 1}$ exists.


In any case, out of all of the possible "extension diagrams" we can consider for a general category $C$, these are the only two that lead to interesting outcomes.

### Starting with a functor $F:C\to D$ and nothing else

Suppose now $F:C\to D$ is a given functor. Following the ideas of the previous set of examples, we can consider all "extension diagrams" that involve this functor. Once again, without knowing anything more about the categories $C$ and $D$, there aren't very many ways to complete an "extension diagram" where one "leg" is the given functor $F:C\to D$. And out of those limited possibilities, there are only two that lead to interesting extensions.

For the first, consider the following diagram:

-60.49, -1.67 -60.49, -6.27 -60.5 M6.41 -60.48 C2.28 -60.49, -1.86 -60.49, -6.27 -60.5 M-6.27 -60.5 C-4.67 -63.9, -3.08 -67.31, 0.09 -74.08 M-6.27 -60.5 C-4.37 -64.56, -2.46 -68.63, 0.09 -74.08 M0.09 -74.08 C0.09 -74.08, 0.09 -74.08, 0.09 -74.08 M0.09 -74.08 C0.09 -74.08, 0.09 -74.08, 0.09 -74.08" stroke="#1e1e1e" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/></g></g><mask/><g transform="translate(10 68.2737707241809) rotate(0 6.883648406522184 5.5929643302992815)"><use href="#image-947eb6cbe021218016aa513e666a76754d16ae9d" width="14" height="11" opacity="1"/></g><g transform="translate(119.53943612207934 112.25918551905733) rotate(0 10.5 5.5)"><use href="#image-2d09cc0206309d47fefe190a1e82d3507152f010" width="21" height="11" opacity="1"/></g><g transform="translate(60.53943612207934 123.25918551905733) rotate(0 9.5 5.5)"><use href="#image-bb7e526b44248e441e4f361fa55f0c8d9f4990e2" width="19" height="11" opacity="1"/></g></svg>

Suppose the left Kan extension of $F$ along $t_C$ exists. It is then a functor $L:{\bf 1}\to D$ together with a natural isomorphism

$$\tau_S: \operatorname{Hom}_{D^{\bf 1}}(L,S)\xrightarrow{\sim} \operatorname{Hom}_{D^C}(F,S\circ t_C).$$

Once again, the functors $L$ and $S$ correspond to objects $l$ and $s$ in $D$, and the set on the left is canonical identified with the set of arrows $l\to s$. As for the set on the right, the functor $S\circ t_C$ sends every object $c\in C$ to the object $s\in D$, so a natural transformation $F\Rightarrow S\circ t_C$ is exactly a "cone" from $F$ to $s$. The above natural bijection is then exactly the condition for the object $l$ (together with the natural isomorphism $\tau$) to be the colimit of the functor $F$. Indeed, the image under $\tau_L$ of the identity arrow $l\to l$ gives the cone from $F$ to $l$ through which all other cones uniquely factor.

It's not hard to prove that the converse is also true, and so we have the following:

> [!summary] Colimits as left Kan extensions
> The left Kan extension of a functor $F:C\to D$ along the terminal functor $t_C:C\to {\bf 1}$ gives a colimit of $F$, and conversely.

Dually, we also have the following result:

> [!summary] Limits as right Kan extensions
> The right Kan extension of a functor $F:C\to D$ along the terminal functor $t_C:C\to {\bf 1}$ gives a limit of $F$, and conversely.

---

Suppose a left Kan extension of $I_C$ along $F$ exists, and let $G=\operatorname{Lan}_F(I_C):D\to C$ denote this functor. This functor comes endowed with a natural isomorphism

$$\tau_S:\operatorname{Hom}_{C^D}(G,S)\xrightarrow{\sim}\operatorname{Hom}_{C^C}(I_C, S\circ F).$$

Consider the special case of the component map when $S=G$. This is a natural bijection

$$\tau_G:\operatorname{Hom}_{C^D}(G,G)\xrightarrow{\sim}\operatorname{Hom}_{C^C}(I_C, G\circ F).$$

Under this bijection, the identity natural transformation on $G$ corresponds to a specific natural transformation $\eta:I_C\Rightarrow G\circ F$.

This situation should feel suspiciously similar. It looks like $G:D\to C$ might be some type of adjoint functor! Indeed, one can prove the following:

> [!summary] Adjoints as Kan extensions
> A left (respectively, right) Kan extension of the identity functor $I_C:C\to C$ along the functor $F:C\to D$ is exactly a functor $G:D\to C$ that is right (respectively, left) adjoint to $F$.

> [!warning] Left versus right
> There is *not* a typo in the above result. The left Kan extension corresponds to a right adjoint, and a right Kan extension corresponds to a left adjoint. Definitely inconvenient for human memory!

If you're interested in the details of this proof (and a lot more about Kan extensions), definitely check out Chapter X in Mac Lane's *Categories for the Working Mathematician*.
